title: Capitalization Rate
equation_latex: \text{C} \times ap R \times at \times e = N \times OI / \text{P} \times ro \times pe \times rt \times y \text{V} \times al \times ue
notes: This equation calculates the capitalization rate for real estate. Cap Rate represents the initial yield on a property, NOI is net operating income, and Property Value is the purchase price or market value. Cap rate is used to compare different properties and determine if an investment is attractive based on current income.

title: Net Operating Income
equation_latex: N \times OI = \text{E} \times ff \times ec \times ti \times ve \text{G} \times ro \times ss \text{I} \times nc \times om \times e - O \times pe \times ra \times ti \times ng \text{E} \times xp \times en \times se \times s
notes: This equation calculates net operating income for real estate. NOI represents the income generated by a property after operating expenses but before debt service and taxes. Effective Gross Income includes rent and other income minus vacancy and collection losses.

title: Effective Gross Income
equation_latex: \text{E} \times GI = \text{P} \times ot \times en \times ti \times al \text{G} \times ro \times ss \text{I} \times nc \times om \times e - \text{V} \times ac \times an \times cy a \times nd \text{C} \times ol \times le \times ct \times io \times n L \times os \times se \times s
notes: This equation calculates effective gross income for real estate. EGI represents the actual income collected from tenants after accounting for vacancy and collection losses. Potential Gross Income is the income if all units were occupied at full rent.

title: Gross Rent Multiplier
equation_latex: \text{G} \times RM = \text{P} \times ro \times pe \times rt \times y \text{P} \times ri \times ce / A \times nn \times ua \times l \text{G} \times ro \times ss R \times en \times t
notes: This equation calculates the gross rent multiplier for real estate. GRM represents how many years of gross rent would be needed to pay for the property. A lower GRM indicates a potentially better investment, though this is a rough metric that doesn't account for expenses.

title: Cash-on-Cash Return
equation_latex: \text{C} \times oC = A \times nn \times ua \times l \text{C} \times as \times h \text{F} \times lo \times w / \text{T} \times ot \times al \text{C} \times as \times h \text{I} \times nv \times es \times te \times d
notes: This equation calculates cash-on-cash return for real estate. CoC represents the annual return on the actual cash invested, Annual Cash Flow is after all expenses and debt service, and Total Cash Invested includes down payment and closing costs.

title: Capital Recovery Factor
equation_latex: \text{C} \times RF = r * (1 + r)^{n} / ((1 + r)^{n} - 1)
notes: This equation calculates the capital recovery factor for mortgage amortization. CRF represents the mortgage payment as a percentage of the loan amount, r is the periodic interest rate, and n is the number of periods. This factor is used in real estate finance calculations.

title: Vacancy Rate
equation_latex: \text{V} \times ac \times an \times cy R \times at \times e = \text{V} \times ac \times an \times t U \times ni \times ts / \text{T} \times ot \times al U \times ni \times ts
notes: This equation calculates the vacancy rate for a property. Vacancy Rate represents the percentage of units that are unoccupied, Vacant Units is the count of empty units, and Total Units is the total number of units. Vacancy impacts effective gross income and NOI.

title: Debt Service Coverage Ratio
equation_latex: D \times SC \times R = N \times OI / A \times nn \times ua \times l D \times eb \times t \text{S} \times er \times vi \times ce
notes: This equation calculates the debt service coverage ratio. DSCR represents the ability to cover debt obligations from operating income, NOI is net operating income, and Annual Debt Service is the total principal and interest payments. Lenders typically require DSCR > 1.2.

title: Loan-to-Value Ratio
equation_latex: L \times \text{TV} = L \times oa \times n A \times mo \times un \times t / \text{P} \times ro \times pe \times rt \times y \text{V} \times al \times ue
notes: This equation calculates the loan-to-value ratio. LTV represents the percentage of the property value financed by debt, Loan Amount is the mortgage principal, and Property Value is the purchase price or appraisal. LTV affects interest rates and loan eligibility.

title: Internal Rate of Return (Real Estate)
equation_latex: 0 = \sum_{t=0}^{n} \frac{\text{CF}_{t}}{\left(1 + \text{IRR}\right)^{t}}
notes: This equation calculates IRR for real estate investments. IRR represents the annualized return accounting for all cash flows including operating income, capital expenditures, refinancing, and sale. Real estate IRR typically targets 10-15%.

title: Multiple on Invested Capital
equation_latex: \text{M} \times OI \times \text{C} = \text{T} \times ot \times al D \times is \times tr \times ib \times ut \times io \times ns / \text{T} \times ot \times al \text{E} \times qu \times it \times y \text{I} \times nv \times es \times te \times d
notes: This equation calculates the multiple on invested capital. MOIC represents the total return as a multiple of the initial investment, Total Distributions include all cash flows to investors, and Total Equity Invested is the total capital called. MOIC is commonly reported by private equity firms.

title: Public Market Equivalent
equation_latex: L \times PM \times \text{E} = s \times um_{t=1}^{n} \text{C} \times F_{t} * (1 + r_{b}e \times nc \times hm \times ar \times k)^{\text{T}}-t / \text{I} \times ni \times ti \times al \text{I} \times nv \times es \times tm \times en \times t
notes: This equation calculates the public market equivalent. LPME represents the multiple achieved relative to a public market benchmark, CF_t are distributions, r_benchmark is the benchmark return, and Initial Investment is the capital deployed. This compares PE performance to public markets.

title: Limited Partner Commitment
equation_latex: L \times \text{P} \text{C} \times om \times mi \times tm \times en \times t = \text{F} \times un \times d \text{S} \times iz \times e * L \times \text{P} \text{P} \times er \times ce \times nt \times ag \times e
notes: This equation calculates the commitment from limited partners. LP Commitment represents the capital pledged by LPs to the fund, Fund Size is the total target capital, and LP Percentage is the LP's ownership percentage. LPs commit capital that is drawn down over time.

title: General Partner Carried Interest
equation_latex: \text{G} \times \text{P} \text{C} \times ar \times ri \times ed \text{I} \times nt \times er \times es \times t = 20% * (\text{T} \times ot \times al D \times is \times tr \times ib \times ut \times io \times ns - R \times et \times ur \times n o \times f \text{C} \times ap \times it \times al)
notes: This equation calculates the general partner carried interest. GP Carried Interest represents the profit share for the GP, which is typically 20% of profits after LPs receive their return of capital. This aligns GP and LP incentives. This equation is fundamental to the time value of money concept, which states that money available at the present time is worth more than the same amount in the future due to its potential earning capacity. The mathematical formulation captures how capital compounds over time, forming the foundation for all discounted cash flow analysis.

title: Catch-Up Provision
equation_latex: L \times \text{P} r \times ec \times ei \times ve \times s 80% u \times nt \times il L \times \text{P} R \times et \times ur \times n o \times f \text{C} \times ap \times it \times al
notes: This equation describes the catch-up provision in PE compensation. After the catch-up, the GP receives a higher percentage (typically 40-50%) until the preferred return is met. This accelerates GP compensation after LPs recover their investment.

title: Preferred Return
equation_latex: L \times \text{P} \text{P} \times re \times fe \times rr \times ed R \times et \times ur \times n = \text{I} \times ni \times ti \times al \text{I} \times nv \times es \times tm \times en \times t * \text{P} \times re \times fe \times rr \times ed R \times at \times e * \text{T} \times im \times e
notes: This equation calculates the preferred return for LPs. LP Preferred Return represents the return that must be paid to LPs before the GP participates in profits, typically 8% annually. This is a key term in PE partnership agreements.

title: Management Fee
equation_latex: \text{M} \times an \times ag \times em \times en \times t \text{F} \times ee = \text{F} \times un \times d \text{S} \times iz \times e * \text{F} \times ee R \times at \times e
notes: This equation calculates the annual management fee. Management Fee represents the fee paid to the GP for managing the fund, typically 1.5-2% of committed capital in early years and 0.5-1% of invested capital in later years.

title: Sharpe Ratio for Hedge Funds
equation_latex: \text{S} \times ha \times rp \times e = (\text{S} \times tr \times at \times eg \times y R \times et \times ur \times n - R \times is \times k-\text{F} \times re \times e R \times at \times e) / \text{S} \times tr \times at \times eg \times y \text{V} \times ol \times at \times il \times it \times y
notes: This equation calculates the Sharpe ratio for hedge fund strategies. Sharpe represents risk-adjusted return, Strategy Return is the absolute return, Risk-Free Rate is the benchmark, and Strategy Volatility is the standard deviation of returns. Hedge fund Sharpe ratios often look attractive due to low volatility.

title: Sortino Ratio
equation_latex: \text{S} \times or \times ti \times no = (R_{p} - R_{f}) / s \times ig \times ma_{d}o \times wn
notes: This equation calculates the Sortino ratio, a downside risk measure. Sortino represents return per unit of downside risk, R_p is portfolio return, R_f is the risk-free rate, and sigma_down is the standard deviation of negative returns. This is preferred for asymmetric return distributions.

title: Calmar Ratio
equation_latex: \text{C} \times al \times ma \times r = A \times nn \times ua \times l R \times et \times ur \times n / \text{M} \times ax \times im \times um D \times ra \times wd \times ow \times n
notes: This equation calculates the Calmar ratio for hedge funds. Calmar represents return per unit of maximum drawdown, Annual Return is the average annual return, and Maximum Drawdown is the largest peak-to-trough decline. This is particularly relevant for trend-following strategies.

title: Information Ratio
equation_latex: \text{I} \times R = (\text{P} \times or \times tf \times ol \times io R \times et \times ur \times n - B \times en \times ch \times ma \times rk R \times et \times ur \times n) / \text{T} \times ra \times ck \times in \times g \text{E} \times rr \times or
notes: This equation calculates the information ratio for hedge funds. IR represents active return per unit of tracking error, which measures how consistently a strategy outperforms its benchmark. Higher IR indicates better skill.

title: Maximum Drawdown
equation_latex: \text{M} \times DD = m \times ax_{t i \times n [0
notes: Alternative Investments - Hedge Funds,This equation calculates the maximum drawdown for hedge funds. MDD represents the largest peak-to-trough decline, Peak_t is the maximum value before the decline, and Trough_t is the lowest value after. Drawdown risk is crucial for evaluating hedge fund strategies.

title: Sterling Ratio
equation_latex: \text{S} \times te \times rl \times in \times g = (R_{p} - R_{f}) / A \times ve \times ra \times ge D \times ra \times wd \times ow \times n
notes: This equation calculates the Sterling ratio. Sterling represents return per unit of average drawdown, R_p is portfolio return, R_f is risk-free rate, and Average Drawdown is the mean of all drawdowns. This complements maximum drawdown with average severity.

title: Burke Ratio
equation_latex: B \times ur \times ke = (R_{p} - R_{f}) / s \times qr \times t \times (s \times um \times (D \times ra \times wd \times ow \times n_{i}^{2}))
notes: This equation calculates the Burke ratio. Burke represents return per unit of root-mean-square drawdown, which weights larger drawdowns more heavily. This is a more conservative measure of drawdown risk.

title: CTA Strategy Return
equation_latex: R_{\text{C}}\text{T} \times A = s \times um_{i=1}^{n} w_{i} * R_{s}t \times ra \times te \times gy
notes: Alternative Investments - Hedge Funds,This equation calculates the return of a multi-strategy CTA. R_CTA represents the overall CTA return, w_i are the strategy weights, and R_strategy,i are the returns of individual strategies. CTA strategies often include trend-following across multiple asset classes.

title: Managed Futures Exposure
equation_latex: \text{E} \times xp \times os \times ur \times e = s \times um_{i=1}^{n} w_{i} * (1 + b \times et \times a_{i}) * V_{i} / \text{T} \times ot \times al \text{V} \times ol
notes: This equation calculates the effective exposure of a managed futures portfolio. Exposure represents the systematic market exposure, w_i are positions, beta_i are market betas, V_i are notional values, and Total Vol is the portfolio volatility. Managed futures can have high effective leverage.

title: Equity Market Neutral Return
equation_latex: R_{\text{E}}\text{M} \times N = a \times lp \times ha + s \times um b \times et \times a_{j} * F_{j} + e \times ps \times il \times on
notes: This equation models the return of an equity market neutral strategy. R_EMN represents the strategy return, alpha is the stock selection skill, beta_j are factor exposures, F_j are factor returns, and epsilon is the idiosyncratic return. Market neutral means zero net market beta.

title: Convertible Bond Delta
equation_latex: D \times el \times ta_{\text{C}}B = (1 - R) * D \times el \times ta_{o}p \times ti \times on / (1 - R + D \times el \times ta_{o}p \times ti \times on)
notes: This equation approximates the delta of a convertible bond. Delta_CB represents the sensitivity to the underlying stock, R is the recovery rate, and Delta_option is the option delta. Convertible bonds have option-like payoffs. Option pricing requires risk-neutral valuation frameworks that adjust expected returns for risk, typically using the risk-free rate rather than expected return under the physical measure.

title: Contingent Convertible (CoCo) Trigger
equation_latex: \text{T} \times ri \times gg \times er = m \times in \times ( \text{C} \times ET \times 1 R \times at \times io
notes: Discretionary,Alternative Investments - Structured Products,This equation defines the trigger for contingent convertible bonds. Trigger represents when the CoCo converts to equity or takes a loss, CET1 Ratio is the core equity tier 1 capital ratio, Capital Ratio is total capital ratio, and Discretionary allows issuer intervention.

title: Tranche Attachment Point
equation_latex: A \times tt \times ac \times hm \times en \times t = L \times os \times s L \times ev \times el w \times he \times re \text{T} \times ra \times nc \times he b \times eg \times in \times s t \times o a \times bs \times or \times b l \times os \times se \times s
notes: This equation defines the attachment point of a structured product tranche. Attachment represents the percentage loss level at which the tranche starts absorbing losses. Lower attachment points mean higher risk and higher yield.

title: Tranche Detachment Point
equation_latex: D \times et \times ac \times hm \times en \times t = A \times tt \times ac \times hm \times en \times t + \text{T} \times ra \times nc \times he W \times id \times th
notes: This equation defines the detachment point of a structured product tranche. Detachment represents the percentage loss level at which the tranche is completely wiped out. The tranche absorbs losses between attachment and detachment.

title: Expected Tranche Loss
equation_latex: \text{E} \times TL = i \times nt \times eg \times ra \times l_{A \times tt \times ac \times h}^{D \times et \times ac \times h} L \times os \times s * \text{P} \times \text{DF} \times (L \times os \times s) d \times Lo \times ss
notes: This equation calculates the expected loss on a structured product tranche. ETL represents the average loss the tranche will incur, PDF(Loss) is the probability density of portfolio losses, and integration is from attachment to detachment. This is key for pricing and risk management.

title: Subordination Level
equation_latex: \text{S} \times ub \times or \times di \times na \times ti \times on = A \times tt \times ac \times hm \times en \times t \text{P} \times oi \times nt / \text{T} \times ot \times al \text{P} \times or \times tf \times ol \times io
notes: This equation calculates the subordination level of a tranche. Subordination represents how much of the portfolio is junior to the tranche, Attachment Point is the loss level where the tranche starts absorbing losses, and Total Portfolio is the full notional. Higher subordination means lower risk.

title: Waterfall Distribution
equation_latex: \text{S} \times en \times io \times r = m \times ax \times (0
notes: Alternative Investments - Structured Products,This equation describes the waterfall distribution in structured products. Senior tranche payments are the remaining cash flow after satisfying junior tranche requirements. Junior tranches absorb losses first, providing credit enhancement to seniors.

title: Collateral Coverage
equation_latex: \text{C} \times ov \times er \times ag \times e = \text{C} \times ol \times la \times te \times ra \times l \text{V} \times al \times ue / \text{S} \times en \times io \times r \text{T} \times ra \times nc \times he N \times ot \times io \times na \times l
notes: This equation calculates the collateral coverage for a structured product. Coverage represents how well the collateral backs the senior tranche, Collateral Value is the mark-to-market value of assets, and Senior Tranche Notional is the senior tranche size. Coverage below 100% increases senior risk.
